avalancheActivity.highlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. Weak layers in the old snowpack are treacherous.
avalancheActivity.comment:
Above approximately 700 m snow will fall on Friday over a wide area. In some regions up to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m. The wind will be strong at times over a wide area.
The sometimes strong wind will transport the new snow. The wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and at transitions into gullies and bowls.
The new snow can be released naturally in all aspects above the tree line. In particular at the base of rock walls numerous small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow.
Avalanche prone weak layers exist in the old snowpack on northwest, north and northeast facing slopes. Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released by large additional loads on steep shady slopes. Especially on very steep shady slopes the avalanches can be released in deep layers of the snowpack and reach medium size.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Faceted weak layers exist in the bottom section of the snowpack especially on west, north and east facing slopes. These can only be released in isolated cases.
At elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
